question: Which statement best describes saltwater upconing near a pumping well in a coastal aquifer?
success: ✅ Correct — pumping reduces freshwater heads and can pull the interface upward toward the well, creating an upconing shape beneath/around the well.
error: ❌ Not quite — upconing is driven primarily by pumping-induced drawdown and the resulting upward movement of the interface, not by dispersion alone.

question: Which of the following changes will generally increase the risk of saltwater upconing at a pumping well? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct — higher pumping rates and screens closer to the interface both increase the likelihood that saltwater will be drawn upward toward the well.
error: ❌ Not quite — the strongest risk factors are higher pumping and a screen placed close to the interface; moving farther inland generally reduces coastal salinization risk.

question: In a sharp-interface conceptual model of upconing, which indicator most directly signals that the well is about to start producing saline water?
success: ✅ Correct — salinization risk becomes critical when the interface rises to the level of the well screen (or very close to it).
error: ❌ Not quite — the key threshold is the interface elevation relative to the well screen, not changes in porosity or a global recharge shutdown.

question: Which mitigation strategies are commonly recommended to reduce saltwater upconing risk? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct — reducing pumping stress and increasing separation between screen and interface (or moving/distributing pumping inland) are standard approaches to lower upconing risk.
error: ❌ Not quite — increasing pumping generally worsens upconing; mitigation focuses on reducing drawdown near the interface and/or increasing separation.

question: Why does a strong vertical hydraulic conductivity (or weak anisotropy) generally increase the tendency for upconing beneath a pumping well?
success: ✅ Correct — when vertical flow is less restricted, pumping-induced vertical gradients can more easily pull the interface upward (stronger deformation).
error: ❌ Not quite — higher vertical conductivity facilitates vertical flow and interface deformation; it does not flatten the interface or remove density effects.

question: In an unconfined coastal aquifer, which statement about pumping-induced drawdown and upconing is most consistent with a sharp-interface interpretation?
success: ✅ Correct — larger drawdown increases vertical gradients near the well and tends to pull the interface upward, raising salinization risk.
error: ❌ Not quite — upconing is strongly linked to pumping-induced drawdown; constant recharge does not prevent interface deformation near the well.
